title: What is the Perrin sequence? - Quora

response.answer_text: Not going to mention anything here which a simple Wikipedia lookup wouldn’t have uncovered, but here goes: An integer sequence depicted by the following recurrence relation: ,  is the Perrin sequence, with ,  and  as the seed values. The way it differs from its more well- known sibling Fibonacci sequence is that it considers the sum of its two predecessors skipping the immediate one, as opposed to: ,  , whose seed values are  and .  Coming back to the sequence under consideration, here are a first few terms of the Perrin sequence less than :  , as defined at OEIS.  Just as an addendum, here is a Python script to find the numbers belonging to the Perrin sequence lesser than upper_limit: #defining the seed values list_1 = [3, 0, 2]; upper_limit = 100;  for i in range(3, 100, 1):     number = list_1[i - 2] + list_1[i - 3];      #breaking out of the loop as soon as the ith Perrin number crosses the upper_limit     if(number > upper_limit):         break;      #appending the number to the list list_1     list_1.append(number);  print(list_1); , which prints out: [3, 0, 2, 3, 2, 5, 5, 7, 10, 12, 17, 22, 29, 39, 51, 68, 90] The code above is quite straightforward, but in case there are some doubts somewhere, I will be more than glad to respond in the comment section.  Kindly have a look here, here, here and here for more information on the topic. Hope that helped. </EOA235>
